unnormalised: Hey everyone! So, I was just on the phone with my Dadi (that's grandma for you non-Hindi speakers!), and we were talking about her amazing aloo parathas. And honestly, trying to follow her recipe is like decoding ancient Sanskrit. Everything is in “a pinch of this” and “a handful of that.” Seriously, a handful to *who*? My giant paws or her petite ones?!
normalised: Hey everyone! So, I was just on the phone with my D-A-D-I (that's grandma for you non-Hindi speakers!), and we were talking about her amazing aloo parathas. unnormalised: It got me thinking – how many of us actually understand cooking measurements beyond, like, the standard cup and spoon? Because let’s be real, when Dadi says “add ½ adrak,” she means add half an inch of ginger. I asked her to elaborate! She measured the ginger with a ruler and asked me to note it.

unnormalised: Then there's the whole thing with volume. My mum always says “add 250 ml doodh” but what if you don’t have a measuring cup handy? I have found that a standard tea cup is about 180 ml, so keep that in mind if you have to guesstimate. I use that when I'm baking cakes. Also, the perfect consistency of Dahi is not too thick and not too watery.
normalised: Then there's the whole thing with volume. My mum always says “add two hundred and fifty milliliter doodh” but what if you don’t have a measuring cup handy? I have found that a standard tea cup is about one hundred and eighty milliliter, so keep that in mind if you have to guesstimate. I use that when I'm baking cakes. Also, the perfect consistency of Dahi is not too thick and not too watery.

unnormalised: And don’t even get me started on weight! A lot of Indian recipes still use tolas. One tola equals approximately 11.66 grams. I know, random right? Grandma uses 'chatak'. A Chatak is about 58 grams. Its still widely used in Kolkata!
normalised: And don’t even get me started on weight! A lot of Indian recipes still use tolas. One tola equals approximately eleven point six six grams. I know, random right? Grandma uses 'chatak'. A chatak is about fifty eight grams. It's still widely used in Kolkata!

unnormalised: The other day, I was making chai and the recipe called for "1 tsp" of elaichi powder. Turned out my teaspoon was HUGE! The chai tasted like pure cardamom. So, lesson learned: standardize your spoons, folks! A level teaspoon is approx 5 ml, that's the standard measurement.
normalised: The other day, I was making chai and the recipe called for "one T-S-P" of elaichi powder. Turned out my teaspoon was H-U-G-E! The chai tasted like pure cardamom. So, lesson learned: standardize your spoons, folks! A level teaspoon is approximately five milliliter, that's the standard measurement.

unnormalised: Another thing, temperature! While most ovens use Celsius, some of the older ones are still in Fahrenheit. Always double-check! Remember, 350°F is roughly equal to 175°C. Otherwise, you’ll end up with burnt cookies, like yours truly did last week.
normalised: Another thing, temperature! While most ovens use Celsius, some of the older ones are still in Fahrenheit. Always double-check! Remember, three hundred and fifty degree Fahrenheit is roughly equal to one hundred and seventy five degree Celsius. Otherwise, you’ll end up with burnt cookies, like yours truly did last week.

unnormalised: So, the next time you’re tackling a traditional recipe, don’t be afraid to ask for clarifications! Or, you know, just wing it. That’s what I usually do. After all, cooking is all about experimenting… and sometimes ending up with hilariously inedible results. I will give you an updated recipe from Grandma soon! Let me decode it first!
